comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Mrs Palmer, her five daughters, and the rest of the community were shocked by the suggestion that they take a bus instead.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "The photo has no identification, but it seems likely that the event depicted is a meeting of Palmer's Community Hiking Association, run by the Sydney department store F.J. Palmer & Sons. A sign to the left of the stage has the words of a song "Palmer's Official Hiking Song - Hike Yourself into Jolly Good Health..." and a crest above bears the initials 'FJP'. A crest to the right of the stage bears the initials 'RRCo'. "F.J. Palmer and Sons Ltd, whose store was situated at the corner of Pitt and Park Streets, were tailors, men's and boys' outfitters, and suppliers of sporting and travel requisites. In 1932 the store sponsored five very popular "mystery hikes" around Sydney offered by the railways." –Object Description

comment.author: 8793648@N06
comment._content: F J Palmer's had numerous stores around Sydney at least, including Bankstown in which I used to shop, and were taken over by Buckingham's who in turn were taken over by by City and Suburban Properties, then by City Resources, which folded in 1991 when delisted for failing to pay their annual company listing fee. Palmer's also published a special children's annual which was sold in their stores in the 1950s.

comment.author: 8203066@N06
comment._content: Clothing style, especially women's hats puts this photograph in the late 1920s, possibly early 1930s time-frame.
